Bedrock

A minimalist boilerplate for Express apps.

View on GitHub

Overview

Bedrock is a quick way to start an Express app with nice defaults without having to worry about setup and configuration. It is a collection of modules and libraries that I find myself using in almost every Express app that I make. Bedrock removes the repetition that is involved when building a new Express app.

Features

Bedrock does the following for you:

  • Sets up your views and layout files
  • Configures a basic Express 4.0 Server
  • Sets up a Handlebars View Engine
  • Exposes useful Handlebars helpers
  • Sets up a place to store config data
  • Creates 404/500 pages
  • Basic Route Handling
  • Loads popular front-end code (jQuery/Pure by default)
  • Shares Handlebars partials with the client
  • Shares JavaScript variables with the client

Stack

By default, Bedrock is built on the following stack:

  • Express 4.x
  • Handlebars View Engine, with express-handlebars
  • Common Handlebars Helpers like , and others to make it easy to load CSS/JS on a per-page basis.
  • Uses express-state to expose data from the server to the client.
  • Allows you to share Handlebars templates/partials between the server and the client.

Installation

You can clone Bedrock when creating a new project. Instead of working off master, you should work off a release tag. The latest release tag is v0.1.2.

git clone --depth 1 git@github.com:tilomitra/bedrock.git <your-app-folder-name>
cd <your-app-folder-name>
git checkout v0.1.2
npm install
npm start

If npm install does not work on your machine for some reason, try doing sudo npm install.

Then, go to http://localhost:8000. I recommend using --depth 1 so that you don't get Bedrock's commit history, which you probably don't care about since you'll be adding your application-specific commits.

Next Steps

At this point, you should have a working server that is rendering out a home page. From here, you can do several things:

  • You can learn about configuring the server.
  • You can start coding up your HTML pages and learn how to render them.
  • If your server needs to pass data to the client, you can learn about sharing code.
